Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Systematics, host-specificity, and genome evolution of holoparasitic plants: A case study in Orobanche (Orobanchaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Parasitism is a unique life history strategy that has evolved independently dozens of times in plants, animals, and other organisms. Due to its high biodiversity and a good understanding of its mode of parasitism, the non-photosynthetic parasitic plant genus Orobanche provides a remarkable opportunity for understanding the unique macro- and microevolutionary consequences of parasitism in a phylogenetic framework. Recent work has identified both evolutionary and genetic consequences, including numerous host specific lineages as well as host-to-parasite horizontal gene transfer. This research will use genomic-scale sequencing of new-world Orobanche and field studies across North America to develop the following: (1) a fine-scale understanding of tempo and mode of genome evolution in parasitic plants, (2) a better understanding of host-breadth, and (3) abiotic and biotic habitat characteristics, with a taxonomic revision to follow. In addition to advancing the fields of evolutionary biology and ecology, an improved understanding of host specificity and parasite genomics may be of use in combating several species of Orobanche that cause severe agricultural damage to tomato, sunflower, and other crops in Europe, Asia, and the Americas. One graduate and several undergraduate students will receive training in laboratory and museum research techniques, and will have the opportunity to present the results at regional and national meetings.

Specifically, we will use a genome skimming approach, coupled with field studies across North America to study (1) fine-scale tempo and mode of plastid and mitochondrial evolution in new-world Orobanche, (2) host-breadth of numerous lineages, (3) abiotic and biotic habitat characteristics to better understand distributions, and (4) diagnosable features of lineages, leading directly to taxonomic revision. Out of several genome reduction techniques available, genome-skimming (whole-genome shotgun sequencing) will provide the most cost-effective way to capture the high-copy fraction of genomic DNA, including the nuclear ribosomal cistron, plastome, and mitogenome, even from degraded material such as that found on herbarium sheets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of research was on the evolution and biodiversity of non-photosynthetic parsitic plants. For the purposes of this study, parasitic plants are defined as plants that have a specialized organ, called a haustorium, that directly attaches to the vascular tissue of another plant in order to acquire nutrients, energy, and other resources. Parasitism has evolved many times in plants, and usually is associated with dramatic morphologial change such as greatly reduced or absent stems, leaves, and roots. This research focuses on a genus of parasitic plants native to the western hemisphere, the genus Aphyllon (Orobanchaceae).

The first objective of this research was to use DNA sequence data to infer a phylogenetic (evolutionary) tree. Understanding the correct relationships is important for putting a group of organisms, and their traits, in an evolutionary context. We sampled many individuals across their geographic and host range and found strong evidence that the number of species in this group is much higher than previously acknowledged, including both rare and widespread species. Each of these species, though difficult to distinguish morphologically, is easily recognizable by its unique association to a group of closely related hosts. Three of these species have been described, and this taxonomic work  will continue beyond the scope of this grant. A further analysis used fossil and other evidence to scale the evolutionary tree to time, and then estimate ancestral geographical ranges based on current range maps. We inferred multiple, recent dispersals from North America to South America, and in one case coincident with the same north-to-south dispersal of a major host.

Understanding the phylgeny of any group of organisms is critical for being able to put any type of trait information into evolutionary context. In our second objective, we sequenced the chloroplast genomes of one or more representative specimens from six species to test the hypothesis that chloroplast genes are lost in a stepwise, punctuated fashion from parasitic plants. The chloroplast genome of parasitic plants is generally smaller than non-parasitic plants, with photosynthesis-related genes often some of the first to be lost. A recent theory of stepwise evolution was developed at the family level, however it had not been well tested at more shallow evolutionary time scales, with very close relatives. We found that close relatives of Aphyllon section Aphyllon  had very similar chloroplast genomes in terms of length and gene content, but they were quite a bit more reduced than its closest previously sequenced relative, which supports rapid gene loss followed by relative evolutionary stasis. Because we knew the ages of these different species, we were also able to put these patterns of gene loss into a temporal context. Finally, we also discovered several instance of host-to-parasite horizontal gene transfer, in which host genes (specificlaly rbcL) were transfered into the parasite  and incorporated into its mitchondrial genome.

Due to advances in sequencing techonology and achieving our first objectives under budget, the scope of the project was expanded to also include a second group of parasitic plants, the dwarf mistletoes (Arecuothobium). Chloroplast genome sequencing of most species of this worldwide genus has been completed, and future efforts will seek to test hypotheses of cryptic host-specific species and reductions in chloroplast genomes to serve as a comparison with our findings in Aphyllon.

In summary, this research advances our understanding of the evoution and biodiversity of parasitic flowering plants, specifically those in the pan-American genus Aphyllon. Our research findings further highlight the ways that the host-parasite relationship can shape the ecology, biogeography, and genetics of plant parasites.


This research grant was in support of the doctoral dissertation work of Co-PI Schneider, who completed his degree in August 2017. As of mid-2018 this grant has supported 5 peer-reviewed articles, with more planned. The increased understanding of biodiveristy and host-specificity in Aphyllon has also informed recent updates to the Jepson eflora of California, and other local and regional botanical references. In addition, this research provided support and training opportunities for four undergraduate researchers, including an honor's thesis student.
